::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE)
```
:::


## Challenge Overview

Today's challenge is to:

1)  read in a data set, and describe the data set using both words and any supporting information (e.g., tables, etc)
2)  tidy data (as needed, including sanity checks)
3)  mutate variables as needed (including sanity checks)
4)  create at least two univariate visualizations
   - try to make them "publication" ready
   - Explain why you choose the specific graph type
5)  Create at least one bivariate visualization
   - try to make them "publication" ready
   - Explain why you choose the specific graph type

[R Graph Gallery](https://r-graph-gallery.com/) is a good starting point for thinking about what information is conveyed in standard graph types, and includes example R code.

(be sure to only include the category tags for the data you use!)

## Read in data

Read in one (or more) of the following datasets, using the correct R package and command.

-   cereal.csv ⭐
-   Total_cost_for_top_15_pathogens_2018.xlsx ⭐
-   Australian Marriage ⭐⭐ 
-   AB_NYC_2019.csv ⭐⭐⭐
-   StateCounty2012.xls ⭐⭐⭐
-   Public School Characteristics ⭐⭐⭐⭐ 
-   USA Households ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cereal = read_csv("_data/cereal.csv")
```
:::


### Briefly describe the data

This dataset lists several popular breakfast cereals by their sodium content, their sugar content, and their type A or C (presumably meaning adult or children's).

## Tidy Data (as needed)

Is your data already tidy, or is there work to be done? Be sure to anticipate your end result to provide a sanity check, and document your work here.

This dataset is already tidy as it is.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Nothing needed here
```
:::


Are there any variables that require mutation to be usable in your analysis stream? For example, do you need to calculate new values in order to graph them? Can string values be represented numerically? Do you need to turn any variables into factors and reorder for ease of graphics and visualization?

Document your work here.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Converting types A and C to numeric values 1 and 2
cereal <- mutate(cereal, Type = recode(Type, "A" = "1", "C" = "2"))

#Checking variable classes and converting them to numeric to enable calculations
class('Sodium')
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "character"
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
class('Sugar')
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "character"
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
class('Type')
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "character"
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
Sodium <- as.numeric('Sodium')
Sugar <- as.numeric('Sugar')
Type <- as.numeric('Type')
class('Sodium')
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "character"
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
class('Sugar')
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "character"
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
class('Type')
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "character"
```
:::
:::


## Univariate Visualizations

I chose to visualize sodium and sugar with histograms because these do a good job of illustrating the distribution of cereals by the amount of each substance they contain. I chose to have 10 bins in each graph because this number provides relatively neat graphs that illustrate that the amount of sodium in cereals clusters around a value just shy of 200 units, while the distribution of the amount of sugar in cereals is relatively uniform

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
summary(cereal)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
    Cereal              Sodium          Sugar           Type          
 Length:20          Min.   :  0.0   Min.   : 0.00   Length:20         
 Class :character   1st Qu.:137.5   1st Qu.: 4.00   Class :character  
 Mode  :character   Median :180.0   Median : 9.50   Mode  :character  
                    Mean   :167.0   Mean   : 8.75                     
                    3rd Qu.:202.5   3rd Qu.:12.50                     
                    Max.   :340.0   Max.   :18.00                     
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(cereal, aes(Sugar)) + geom_histogram(bins = 10)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](MattEckstein_hw5_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(cereal, aes(Sodium)) + geom_histogram(bins = 10)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](MattEckstein_hw5_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-2.png){width=672}
:::
:::



## Bivariate Visualization(s)


I chose to make a scatterplot in order to see any relationship between the amount of sodium in a cereal and the amount of sugar in one - there is no apparent strong relationship, it turns out.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(cereal, aes(Sodium, Sugar)) + geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](MattEckstein_hw5_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
